entry.para: Dos
Don’ts
Do gather broad background information
Don’t focus on the presenting problem to the exclusion of potentially helpful contextual information
Do rely upon a semi-structured clinical interview to aid with differential diagnosis and determination of each diagnostic criteria
Don’t foreclose on a diagnosis or an explanation for the client’s presenting problem
Do identify the cues (controlling stimuli) and fear response (e. g., fear, anxiety, panic, sensations, etc.), and critically evaluate the terms that the client uses
Don’t accept clients’ use of terms uncritically
Do get concrete examples
Don’t accept clients’ summary characterizations or reports of what usually or generally happens
Do use in vivo or thought experiments to explore the boundaries of the controlling stimulus
Don’t assume that the presence of a stimulus before a fear response guarantees it as a controlling stimulus unless its presence always evokes a fear response
Do adopt a professional demeanor, refraining from judgment about the rationality of client’s behaviors
Don’t assume that being warm and friendly will put socially anxious clients at ease
Do view the client’s behavior during the interview dispassionately
Don’t respond to client panic or anxiety by panicking or becoming anxious
Do make use of information from third parties (e. g., informants, referral sources, etc.)
Don’t rely only on the client’s report when other data are available
Do look for opportunities to affirm the client’s agency
Don’t reinforce the client’s conflation of ability with willingness

Do allow for under- and over-reporting; consider the client’s attitude toward the assessment, including the impacts of the referral context and the client’s history with regard to expressing need and seeking help
Don’t reinforce the client’s distortion (minimization, exaggeration) of their symptoms
Do present the diagnosis as a frame of potential value
Don’t reify the disorders
